Award.AwardTitle: A Building-Block Approach to Tele-healthcare Engineering Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing a set of learning materials and laboratory modules in tele-healthcare to be used in undergraduate electrical and computer engineering curricula. The materials are organized into five project-lab trees and ten topic-subject trees that are self-contained and that may be used in any order. Specific topics covered by the new laboratory materials include design project in cardiac monitoring, mental health monitoring, medical security and long-distance medical transmission. The learning materials are being developed using a four-dimensional pedagogy that engages students with different learning preferences and allows for asynchronous delivery. The project includes rigorous formative and summative evaluation plans with both qualitative and quantitative components coordinated by an experienced independent evaluator. The evaluation plan is designed to establish the quality of the materials and to ensure the project goals are met. The projects results are being disseminated through conferences and journal publications and through direct contact with four other institutions of higher education with diverse student bodies. The materials developed in this project are being placed in the NSF sponsored National Science Digital Library.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This educational development has successfully achieved the following 5 outcomes: (please refer to our project website: http://feihu.eng.ua.edu/NSF_TUES/ for our developed course materials)

(1) Course - One semester course on telehealthcare engineering: Although Tele-Healthcare Engineering is such an important field, unfortunately most schools do not have systematic undergraduate educational materials on tele-healthcare design. One of the reasons is due to the challenge of developing tele-healthcare materials in a multi-disciplinary context (across healthcare principles, computer networking, and embedded systems). We have developed a 16-week course called ECE 400 – Tele-healthcare Engineering, which includes the following important topics: bio-signal processing, pattern recognition from bio-signals, networking for medical applications, medical sensors, implantable medical devices, medical security and privacy, and home-oriented healthcare, and so on. We have developed the lecture slides and provided the corresponding reading materials for each class. This course can be taught in ECE (electrical and computer engineering), computer science, bioengineering, information sciences, and other majors.  

(2) Labs – Well-structured labs for any relevant undergraduate courses: Inspired by kids' building blocks that could be assembled into an object however with good modularity (i.e. the building blocks can be easily reshuffled and assembled into different smaller objects), we have developed 5 labs (the topics include cardiac monitoring, mental health, sensor/RFID integration, medical security, and long-distance medical transmission). Those 5 labs are independent, i.e. there are no time order and context requirements among them. Therefore, each lab can be used for senior project class or in different engineering courses (such as real-time systems, circuit /digital design, wireless communications, etc.).

(3) Projects – Senior Design projects on telehealthcare topics: We have also designed a few senior projects that are suitable to 4~6 student groups. Each project has the hardware design (such as ECG or EEG sensor design) as well as software design (such as sensor signal processing). Those projects can also be used for the semester-long courses since the students can perform different tasks in each week.

(4) Students training: Attracted more engineering students to pursue telehealthcare research: By learning our developed tele-healthcare course and labs/projects, the students have shown stronger desire to pursue biomedical research. Some of them decide to pursue graduate studies in biomedical fields. The senior design teams have found the telemedicine hardware/software designs are extremely helpful in putting what they have learned in ECE major together into a complete project. Some of them successfully obtained good jobs in relevant fields.

(5) Benefits to higher education: Results have been disseminated to other schools: We have broadcasted our course materials to other schools through emails, phone calls, publications, and websites.
